title: The Network vs the Application: Who's to Blame?
description: A tutorial demonstrating how to determine whether slow application performance stems from network issues or application problems, using packet capture analysis and protocol understanding to diagnose the root cause.

title: How to Do TCP Sequence Number Analysis
description: Demonstrates practical TCP sequence number analysis techniques in Wireshark, covering sequence numbers, ACK behavior, and interpreting Wireshark expert info. Includes downloadable packet capture files for practice.

title: First Steps: What to Do When You Don't Have Much to Go On
description: Addresses how to begin investigating a performance issue when minimal information is provided. Outlines an approach to gathering context and demonstrates practical packet analysis techniques for identifying common performance indicators.

title: How to Troubleshoot Throughput and TCP Windows
description: Tutorial demonstrating how to analyze network packet captures to identify whether throughput limitations stem from sender or receiver constraints, using real-world examples. Includes two packet capture files for hands-on analysis.

title: How to Prove It's Not the Network
description: Tutorial on using packet analysis to isolate performance problems among network, server, and application layers. Demonstrates techniques to definitively determine where issues originate rather than making assumptions.

title: How to Hack a Cisco Router ACL
description: Demonstrates how to bypass Cisco router ACL protections by manipulating TCP flags using divert sockets. Covers connecting to ACL-protected servers and modifying packet behavior, with practical challenges and implementation resources.

title: Connecting Windows 10 to Netgear ReadyNAS with SMB
description: Case study resolving a connectivity issue between Windows 10 and an older Netgear ReadyNAS Duo (Sparc Linux) by identifying and fixing an SMB protocol problem using network analysis tools.

title: Troubleshooting Slow FTP Uploads
description: Case study examining why video team FTP uploads to cloud storage experienced significant performance degradation following a firewall replacement. Explores TCP window size as the underlying cause.

title: Troubleshooting a One-Way Performance Issue
description: Case study examining how to diagnose asymmetrical network performance problems using packet analysis, emphasizing the importance of capturing traffic from both sender and receiver perspectives.

title: Troubleshooting MTU Problems With Wireshark
description: Case study demonstrating how packet analysis with Wireshark can quickly identify MTU-related network issues. Discusses TCP Segmentation Offload and the DF (Don't Fragment) bit.

title: Solving Tomcat Throughput Issues on Windows
description: Real-world case study examining poor Tomcat file download performance on Windows 2008R2. Shows how delayed ACK behavior and small send buffers (64KB) conspire to bottleneck throughput even when other services perform normally.

title: Case Study: All Web Pages Load Slooooowly
description: Real-world case study where packet analysis techniques are used to identify why web pages load slowly, walking through the diagnostic process that led to solving the performance issue.

title: When is a Fast Retransmission Not a Fast Retransmission?
description: Examines TCP fast retransmission behavior, challenging readers to determine whether a specific packet represents an actual retransmission or an out-of-order packet. Discusses RFC 2581 standards and duplicate acknowledgments.

title: Command line: Using tcpdump to find scanning activity
description: A guide demonstrating how to identify network scanning activity using tcpdump and command-line tools, explaining how to find a source IP initiating lots of connections and detect port scanning by analyzing packet captures.

title: How Can the Packet Size Be Greater than the MTU?
description: Explains why Wireshark captures show packets exceeding the 1500-byte MTU on the sending host, covering TCP Segmentation Offload (TSO/LSO/GSO) and Large Receive Offload (LRO/RSC) where NICs coalesce received segments.

title: Understanding Throughput and TCP Windows
description: Examines how data transmission rates are controlled through multiple factors including receive window, send window, congestion control, and buffer size. Covers bandwidth-delay product calculation.

title: Why Should You Learn Packet Analysis?
description: Explores motivations for learning packet analysis skills. Argues that packet-level protocol analysis is essential for IT professionals seeking to resolve complex network problems, eliminate blame-shifting between teams, and gain recognition as a technical expert.

title: Understanding the tcptrace Time-Sequence Graph in Wireshark
description: A guide explaining how to interpret the tcptrace time-sequence graph in Wireshark, including the meaning of different lines, colors, and markings used to analyze TCP data streams and network performance.

title: Intelligence in Threat Hunting
description: Start your journey with Intelligence in Threat Hunting, an engaging and practical course designed to deepen your understanding of cyber threat intelligence in modern defense strategies. This course explores the role of strategic, operational, tactical, and technical intelligence across the full intelligence lifecycle, from planning to dissemination. You'll learn how to apply real-world intelligence cycles, analyze adversaries using MITRE ATT&CK, enrich and contextualize indicators of compromise, and integrate CTI into SIEMs and detection workflows. By mastering intelligence-driven methodologies and frameworks like STIX, TAXII, and the Traffic Light Protocol, you’ll be equipped to transform raw data into actionable insights for proactive threat hunting.

title: SOC Ticketing & Reporting
description: SOC Ticketing & Reporting introduces you to the essential processes used to track, manage, and communicate security incidents within a Security Operations Center. You'll learn how to document findings, escalate issues, and maintain clear, actionable records using industry-standard ticketing systems. The course covers effective reporting techniques that help translate technical data into insights for different audiences, including management and other IT teams. By the end, you’ll be equipped to streamline workflows, improve collaboration, and ensure incidents are handled with clarity and accountability.

title: SOC Tools & Technology
description: SOC Tools & Technology provides a hands-on introduction to the key platforms and systems used in today’s Security Operations Centers. You’ll explore the core functions of SIEMs, endpoint detection tools, threat intelligence platforms, and network monitoring solutions, gaining insight into how they work together to support security operations. The course also covers tool selection, configuration, and integration best practices. By understanding the capabilities and limitations of common SOC technologies, you’ll be better prepared to investigate threats, respond to incidents, and support a resilient security posture.

title: Critical Thinking for IT & Cybersecurity
description: Start your journey with Critical Thinking for IT & Cybersecurity, an engaging course designed to build foundational thinking skills for new professionals. You’ll explore why critical thinking is essential and master core elements like analysis, evaluation, inference, explanation, and self-regulation. Through practical scenarios including incident response and threat identification exercises, you'll learn to apply these skills in real-world contexts. The course also examines high-profile case studies to highlight both missed opportunities and successful applications of critical thinking. By the end, you’ll be equipped to adapt to emerging threats and make smarter, evidence-based security decisions.   Attention: This course is presented by an AI instructor and was developed using AI-assisted workflows alongside INE’s standard content processes. All material was reviewed, refined, validated, and approved by INE’s expert content team to ensure accuracy, relevance, and instructional quality.

title: Offensive AI: Generative AI for Pentesters
description: Generative AI for Pentesters is designed for penetration testers, red teamers, and security practitioners looking to integrate generative AI safely and effectively into real-world offensive security workflows. Assuming a solid foundation in pentesting, the course focuses on demystifying AI concepts with a clear, practical approach—avoiding hype and unnecessary complexity. You’ll learn how AI, machine learning, and large language models work, how generative AI produces output, and why prompt engineering is critical for consistent and reliable results. The course also explores widely used AI tools and frameworks, ethical and operational considerations, and actionable techniques for using AI to support analysis and boost productivity. By the end, you’ll be equipped to responsibly incorporate generative AI into your pentesting processes while maintaining accuracy, scope control, and professional integrity.

title: Measuring Network Performance with IP SLA
description:
Understanding whether a network is simply reachable is no longer enough. Modern networks require visibility into performance, reliability, and degradation, and Cisco IP Service Level Agreements (IP SLAs) provide the tools to deliver that insight. In Measuring Network Performance with IP SLAs, you’ll learn how IP SLAs actively generate traffic to measure reachability, latency, and network behavior. The course focuses on how IP SLAs are configured, scheduled, and monitored, with practical emphasis on ICMP-based SLAs and real-world use cases. You’ll also see how IP SLAs integrate with Object Tracking to influence routing decisions and enable intelligent failover, as well as how IP SLA Reaction Configurations can generate syslog messages and SNMP traps when performance thresholds are exceeded.

The course includes quizzes and hands-on labs to reinforce learning and improve retention, allowing you to observe and validate IP SLA behavior in realistic network topologies. By the end, you’ll be ready to use IP SLAs as a proactive tool for measuring and maintaining network performance.

title: Introduction to the SOC
description: Start your journey with Introduction to the SOC, an engaging foundational course that helps you understand how Security Operations Centers operate. This course introduces the core operations of a SOC, exploring essential roles, responsibilities, and workflows that drive threat detection and response. You’ll learn key frameworks like the Cyber Kill Chain, the NIST Cybersecurity Framework, and MITRE ATT&CK, as well as practical concepts like DFIR, SOC tools, and maturity levels. Whether you're new to cybersecurity or transitioning into a SOC role, this course will equip you with the knowledge to navigate and contribute to a modern security operations environment confidently.

title: Incident Detection & Response in the SOC
description: Incident Detection & Response is an engaging and foundational course that introduces the essential concepts and workflows of modern incident response. You'll begin by exploring what incident response is, the role of IR teams, and how to distinguish between events, alerts, and incidents. The course then dives into detecting suspicious activity, including phishing, credential attacks, malware infections, and network intrusions. You'll learn how to validate and triage alerts, use response playbooks, and document incidents effectively. By the end of the course, you'll be equipped with practical skills to handle common security threats and follow structured incident response procedures.

title: Controller-Based Network Automation
description: Controller-Based Network Automation is a practical course designed to introduce you to the core principles and tools used in centralized network automation. In this course, you'll explore how controllers enable scalable and efficient management of network infrastructure through APIs, templates, and policy-driven workflows. You'll gain hands-on experience with leading controller platforms as you learn to automate configurations, monitor network performance, and streamline operations. Whether you're transitioning from device-level scripting or beginning your automation journey, this course lays the foundation for building controller-based solutions that align with modern network architectures.

title: AI in Automation
description: AI in Automation is an introductory course that explores how artificial intelligence is transforming network and IT automation. You’ll learn how machine learning, data analysis, and intelligent decision-making can be integrated into automation workflows to create smarter, more adaptive systems. This course provides a high-level understanding of key AI concepts and their practical applications in network management, fault detection, and predictive maintenance. Whether you're an automation professional or new to AI, this course will help you understand the value of AI-driven solutions and how they can enhance the efficiency, scalability, and intelligence of your automation strategies.

title: Getting Personal with WPA3 Wi-Fi Security
description: Getting Personal with WPA3 Wi-Fi Security is a hands-on, practitioner-oriented deep dive into modern 802.11 security. The course builds from Wi-Fi key management fundamentals and the RSN framework—covering PMK/PTK derivation and the 4-way EAPOL handshake—to the evolution from WPA2 to WPA3, emphasizing why PBKDF2-based PSKs are crackable and how SAE (Dragonfly) delivers per-session keys and forward secrecy. You’ll configure and validate WPA3 features, including Protected Management Frames, Beacon Protection (BIGTK/MME), and WPA3 Transition/Transition-Disable, and explore open-network hardening via OWE (Enhanced Open) as well as WPA3 Easy Connect (DPP) workflows. Along the way, you’ll see where and how to implement these capabilities on Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLCs and current AP platforms, and be able to explain, differentiate, and defend modern WLAN security designs in production.

title: Embedded Event Manager (EEM)
description: Take your Cisco automation skills to the next level with this deep dive into one of the most powerful, yet underused features of Cisco IOS, the Embedded Event Manager (EEM). EEM is a built-in automation framework for Cisco IOS that allows you to program network devices to react intelligently to events in real time. In this course, you'll start by exploring the EEM architecture, core components, and event detectors that form the foundation of automated device behavior. Then, through live demos and guided labs, you'll learn to build and deploy EEM applets to automate routine tasks such as configuration backups and change tracking, enforce security by blocking risky CLI commands, integrate EEM with Enhanced Object Tracking to improve resiliency and trigger automated failover for advanced use cases, and integrate EEM with the IOS GuestShell and Python for advanced use cases. By the end of the course, you'll have the practical hands-on experience needed to build and deploy event-driven automation policies that simplify operations, enhance uptime, and streamline troubleshooting of Cisco IOS-based network devices.

title: Device-Level Network Automation
description: Device-Level Network Automation is a hands-on course designed to introduce you to the fundamentals of automating tasks directly on network devices. You’ll start by exploring tools like Netmiko, Ncclient, and RESTCONF, then move on to building complete automation solutions using Python. The course also introduces Ansible for configuration management and guides you through real-world use cases, including Day-0 provisioning and troubleshooting. By the end, you’ll be equipped to construct on-box automations and streamline device-level operations. Whether you're new to automation or looking to enhance your skills, this course provides the practical knowledge needed to get started confidently.

title: Network Automation Foundation
description: Start your journey with Network Automation Foundation, an engaging and foundational course designed to introduce you to model-driven network automation. This course covers essential concepts such as YANG data modeling, NETCONF, and RESTCONF, while guiding you through key distinctions between native CLI and model-driven automation. You’ll learn how to interpret YANG model structures, construct data payloads, and implement telemetry and configuration changes on IOS-XE devices. By exploring real-world solutions and hands-on demonstrations, you'll gain the technical skills needed to automate network operations using standardized protocols and tools confidently.

title: Getting There with Wireless Mobility & Roaming
description: Getting There with Wireless Mobility and Roaming is a professional-level course designed for Wi-Fi engineers seeking to deepen their understanding of seamless client mobility in enterprise environments. With a focus on Cisco Access Points and Catalyst 9800 Wireless LAN Controllers, this course goes deep into Wi-Fi roaming theory and optimization techniques. It also includes lab demonstrations and packet capture analysis to show how clients discover, authenticate, and transition between APs. Learners explore key concepts, including Layer 2 vs. Layer 3 roaming, mobility groups and tunnels, fast secure roaming mechanisms (such as 802.11r, OKC, 802.11v, and legacy methods), as well as monitoring tools and best practices for optimizing performance. Through detailed explanations, lab demonstrations, and detailed packet captures, participants gain the expertise needed to implement and analyze roaming in Cisco-based wireless networks.

title: Cisco ACI Multi-Site & Advanced Integrations
description: This course takes your Cisco ACI skills to the next level with advanced integrations and multi-site deployments. You’ll learn how to connect ACI with virtualization platforms using Virtual Machine Manager (VMM), implement service graphs for network services, and scale deployments with Multi-Pod and Multi-Site. The course also introduces the Cisco Nexus Dashboard Orchestrator (NDO) to simplify cross-site policy and connectivity management. By the end, you’ll be able to design and deploy enterprise-grade, multi-site ACI solutions with centralized orchestration and automation.

title: Cisco ACI Connectivity & Traffic Control
description: This course focuses on how Cisco ACI enforces traffic policies and extends connectivity beyond the fabric. You’ll learn to implement contracts, filters, and Endpoint Security Groups (ESGs) to manage traffic flows, as well as explore VRF enforcement and group policies. The course then dives into external connectivity, including Layer 2 and Layer 3 integration, EIGRP, OSPF, BGP, high availability, and Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD). By completing this course, you’ll gain the skills to secure, control, and extend ACI deployments with flexible connectivity options.

title: Incident Response: Digital Forensics
description:
This course will introduce you to the core principles, processes, and tools that define modern digital forensics in the context of incident response. The course begins by grounding you in the fundamentals of forensic science, before transitioning into the role of digital forensics within incident response. You’ll then explore the digital forensics process, legal foundations, and the critical importance of maintaining the chain of custody. From there, the course moves into practical evidence handling—covering types and sources of digital evidence, how to set up a digital forensics lab, and the processes of identification and collection. Hands-on demonstrations will guide you through collecting volatile data, memory acquisition with FTK Imager, disk imaging, and ensuring evidence integrity with hashing. You’ll also learn to perform memory forensics using Volatility, as well as file and document forensics, including PDF and macro-enabled document analysis, PE file header analysis, and Windows Registry investigations.

By the end, you will not only understand the theoretical foundations of digital forensics but will also have the ability to apply practical forensic techniques to real-world incidents, from evidence acquisition to analysis. This course is ideal for incident responders, SOC analysts, and cybersecurity professionals seeking to develop a structured and practical understanding of digital forensics, with a focus on the tools, techniques, and processes necessary to investigate and respond effectively to security incidents.

title: Using Generative AI for Networking Automation
description: This course introduces IT and network professionals to the transformative intersection of Generative AI and network automation. Designed for both beginners and experienced engineers, the course begins with foundational concepts and gradually advances to hands-on demonstrations showcasing the power of AI-driven automation.  Learners will begin with an overview of network automation, including its purpose, benefits, and common tools, and then explore the capabilities of Generative AI, specifically how large language models can streamline and enhance network tasks. The course then transitions to two practical demo sessions where real-world use cases are addressed.   By the end of the course, students will have a clear understanding of how to incorporate Generative AI into their automation workflows to improve efficiency, reduce errors, and accelerate network operations.

title: Fast-Track WLAN Deployment Using Cisco Catalyst Center
description: This course is designed for professional-level network engineers seeking to deepen their understanding of the Cisco Catalyst Center (CCC) appliance and its integration with both greenfield and brownfield Catalyst 9800 Wireless LAN Controllers (WLCs). Learners will gain practical insights into preparing and onboarding Catalyst 9800 WLCs into the CCC environment, using a variety of techniques as well as the steps involved in provisioning those WLAN Controllers. The course emphasizes navigating the CCC Web UI to design and deploy wireless networks efficiently by creating and applying WLANs, VLANs, Network Profiles, and other necessary constructs. Through real-world examples and detailed walkthroughs, participants will learn to leverage CCC’s intent-based design model to streamline wireless infrastructure deployment and policy enforcement across enterprise environments.

title: Intelligence in Threat Hunting (Retiring Soon)
description: Start your journey with Intelligence in Threat Hunting, an engaging and practical course designed to deepen your understanding of cyber threat intelligence in modern defense strategies. This course explores the role of strategic, operational, tactical, and technical intelligence across the full intelligence lifecycle, from planning to dissemination. You'll learn how to apply real-world intelligence cycles, analyze adversaries using MITRE ATT&CK, enrich and contextualize indicators of compromise, and integrate CTI into SIEMs and detection workflows. By mastering intelligence-driven methodologies and frameworks like STIX, TAXII, and the Traffic Light Protocol, you’ll be equipped to transform raw data into actionable insights for proactive threat hunting.     Course Update Notice! Based on recent learner feedback, we’re releasing an updated version of this course with improvements and refinements. This current version will remain available through February 20, 2026. You can access the new version here:

title: Endpoint Threat Hunting
description: Endpoint Threat Hunting is an engaging and practical course focused on detecting and analyzing threats at the endpoint level. You’ll begin by exploring core concepts and common endpoint-focused indicators of compromise, followed by deep dives into Windows-specific artifacts such as processes, services, scheduled tasks, and Sysmon logs. The course then guides you through hands-on threat hunting using Splunk and ELK, where you'll learn to write effective queries and investigate suspicious behavior. By mastering these tools and techniques, you’ll gain the skills to identify threats and proactively strengthen endpoint security in real-world environments.

title: Incident Response: Analysis
description: Building on the foundations of the previous course, Incident Response: Detection, this course guides you through key analysis phases, including deep-dive investigations, evidence triage, and log analysis. You’ll learn how to interpret endpoint and network data, distinguish between live and dead-box analysis, and use tools like Splunk, Wireshark, and EvtxECmd. By mastering techniques for analyzing PCAPs, system logs, and network activity, you'll be equipped to respond confidently to complex incidents and uncover critical forensic insights.

title: Incident Response: Detection
description: This course explores the role of detection in identifying and managing security threats through events, alerts, and incidents. You'll dive into endpoint, network, and application log sources, learn how to work with Windows and Linux logging, and understand centralized log collection using tools like Splunk and the ELK Stack. By developing detection rules, analyzing indicators of compromise, and managing alert noise, you’ll build the skills needed to identify real threats effectively. This course lays the technical foundation for the next step: Incident Response Analysis.

title: Cisco Platforms
description: This course is designed to build your proficiency in automating and integrating Cisco technologies using APIs. You’ll explore how to make API calls across a range of Cisco solutions, including Webex, Meraki, DNA Center, Firepower, Intersight, and UCS Manager. This hands-on course helps you understand the unique capabilities and interfaces of each platform, enabling streamlined network operations and efficient device management. Whether you're managing collaboration tools, data center infrastructure, or enterprise networks, this course equips you with practical API skills to modernize your Cisco environment.

title: Infrastructure & Automation
description: This course explores core topics such as network provisioning, management systems, zero-touch provisioning, and software-defined networking. You'll gain hands-on experience with APIs, NETCONF, RESTCONF, and model-driven telemetry, while also diving into infrastructure-as-code tools like Ansible, Terraform, Puppet, and Chef. From understanding intent-based networking to deploying application containers and edge computing solutions, this course equips you with practical skills for real-world environments. Whether you're transitioning to automated infrastructure or optimizing existing systems, this course provides the foundation you need to succeed.

title: Enterprise Network Design Scenarios
description: Build confidence for the CCIE Enterprise Infrastructure Lab Exam and Cisco Certified Design Expert (CCDE) Practical Exam with this scenario-based course, designed to mirror the way design challenges are presented in the real exams. Each design case is framed as a narrative that includes email exchanges, supporting diagrams, and CLI outputs, focusing on topics such as Layer 2 protocols, enterprise IP routing with EIGRP, OSPF, BGP, and MPLS, software-defined networking with SD-WAN, network security, and more. As you progress, you’ll be asked to make key design decisions—analyzing requirements, weighing trade-offs, and selecting the best solutions under exam-like constraints.   This course is tailored for engineers preparing for the Design Module of the CCIE Enterprise Infrastructure Lab Exam , and for the CCDE Practical Exam , where success depends on high-level reasoning and solution design, not command-line skills. By practicing with these immersive, exam-style scenarios, you’ll sharpen your critical thinking, analysis, and decision-making skills, giving you the confidence to perform under the pressure that Cisco’s expert-level exams demand.     Important Information In the actual exams, backwards navigation is disabled in the testing engine. We recommend attempting each design scenario for the first time without using the back button , as information revealed in later emails, diagrams, etc. will often point to the previous correct answers. Once you have completed a scenario, you may re-attempt it and browse forwards and backwards through the questions to better understand why the solution answers are correct. At the end of each scenario attempt, you can review the questions that were marked wrong. To review the full correct solution path for a scenario, click through the quiz without answering any questions (this will result in a score of 0/10 ) and then reveal the solutions for all questions.

title: Mastering Mobile Security & Malware Analysis
description: Mastering Mobile Security & Malware Analysis is an in-depth course designed for anyone ready to explore the dynamic world of mobile cybersecurity. You’ll start by learning the foundations of mobile reverse engineering and essential tools for analysis. The course delves into runtime architectures, advanced security bypass techniques, and both code obfuscation and de-obfuscation. You’ll also examine security for hybrid apps and WebView components, then shift into hands-on mobile malware analysis and penetration testing on smart devices. With coverage of secure development practices and future trends, this course equips you with the technical expertise to defend against evolving mobile threats.

title: Mobile Application Penetration Testing Techniques
description: This immersive and comprehensive learning path is designed for penetration testers and IT security professionals aiming to master mobile security. It covers a wide spectrum of topics, including Android and iOS platforms, application security, static and dynamic analysis, and the OWASP Mobile Top 10. You'll gain hands-on experience with advanced tools like Frida, IDA Pro, and Ghidra, while exploring real-world attack vectors such as reverse engineering, obfuscation bypass, and malware analysis. With advanced modules on hybrid apps, smart TVs, and secure mobile app development, you’ll be fully prepared for the eMAPT exam and certification, ensuring your expertise stays current in the rapidly evolving mobile threat landscape.

title: Wireless Without the Headache: Starting Out with the 9800 WLC
description: Wireless Without the Headache: Starting Out with the 9800 WLC is a beginner-friendly video course designed to help you confidently deploy your first Cisco 9800 Wireless LAN Controller. Whether physical or virtual, this course introduces you to the platform’s role in managing wireless networks and walks you through accessing the Web UI, understanding the tag-and-profile configuration model, and creating a secure WPA2/WPA3 PSK-based WLAN ready for use in your corporate environment. You’ll also learn how to scale that WLAN across an entire campus by mapping it to multiple VLANs using different Policy Tags, providing site-specific client segmentation while keeping the user experience consistent. Finally, the course equips you with practical troubleshooting techniques for Access Points that fail to join the controller, including a demonstration of the powerful Radioactive Trace tool to help you diagnose join-related issues with confidence.

title: Incident Response: Preparation
description: This course will introduce you to the core principles, teams, and frameworks that define modern incident response. This course begins by providing you with an overview of why incident response is critical, the types of incidents and attack vectors organizations face, and the various structures and roles of IR teams. It then explores industry-standard frameworks like the NIST and SANS IR processes, followed by practical guidance on developing IR policies, plans, playbooks, and responsibility matrices. The course concludes by showing you how to build a technological backbone for response, in the form of developing an Incident Response Toolkit, and how to use real-world Incident Management platforms like TheHive. This course is ideal for aspiring incident responders, SOC analysts, and cybersecurity professionals seeking a formal introduction to modern incident response, with a specific focus on building a structured and practical understanding of the Preparation phase of IR.

title: Introduction to Security Operations Center (SOC)
description: Start your journey with Introduction to Security Operations Center (SOC), an engaging foundational course designed for cybersecurity students exploring careers in threat detection and response. This course covers the core functions of a SOC, including roles across SOC tiers, incident response workflows, threat intelligence integration, and key technologies like SOAR and AI-driven automation. You’ll explore SOC maturity models, team structures such as CSIRT and red teams, and frameworks like the NIST 800-61 response lifecycle. By analyzing real-world case studies and understanding practical SOC workflows, you’ll gain essential knowledge and skills to support modern security operations environments and incident response readiness.

title: Introduction to Mobile Application Security
description: Start your journey with Introduction to Mobile Application Security, an engaging foundational course designed to explore the essential aspects of securing mobile platforms. This course introduces the unique challenges of mobile app security, covering app types, testing methodologies, and common vulnerabilities. You’ll dive into the architecture and security features of both Android and iOS, including APK and IPA file analysis and manifest inspection. Explore secure development practices through threat modeling and the OWASP Mobile Top 10. With hands-on static analysis and reporting exercises, you’ll develop practical skills crucial for penetration testing and secure app development in today’s mobile-first world.

title: Network Threat Hunting
description: Network-based hunting focuses on utilizing network traffic and resources to discover intrusions into an enterprise network. This course introduces the fundamentals of network hunting, including key indicators of compromise and methods for identifying malicious activity. You’ll learn to capture and analyze network traffic using tools like Wireshark and NetworkMiner, while gaining a deep understanding of common protocols and how to spot abnormal patterns in ICMP, DHCP, DNS, and HTTP traffic. By applying real-world techniques in traffic capture and packet analysis, you'll be equipped to detect threats and enhance your organization's security posture through proactive network defense.

title: Introduction to Threat Hunting
description: Introduction to Threat Hunting is an essential course for beginners or those with little experience in cybersecurity threat hunting. You’ll explore fundamental concepts, key strategies, and common terminology to build a strong foundation in proactive threat detection. Learn to prepare your organization with effective logging, maturity assessments, and the right investigative mindset. By the end of the course, you’ll better understand what threat hunting is, and its importance in any size organization.

title: Threat Hunting Strategies
description: Threat Hunting Strategies is an in-depth course designed to help you understand the different types of threat hunts and how to start them. You’ll start by understanding attacker motivations and common threat vectors before diving into advanced malware analysis. We then explore structured, unstructured, and situational threat hunting methodologies, guiding you through hypothesis formation and data analysis. By the end, you’ll be prepared to start planning for effective hunts and identify hidden threats, and enhance cybersecurity defenses.

title: Application Deployment & Security
description: Application Deployment & Security is a comprehensive course designed to give you a strong foundation in modern deployment practices and secure application design. You’ll explore the evolution of deployment responsibilities, learn how to implement and optimize CI/CD pipelines, and understand various deployment methods used over time. The course also covers software operability through the 12-Factor App methodology. On the security side, you’ll dive into privacy protection, IT secret management, public key infrastructure, and application-level security techniques including OAuth. This path equips you with practical skills for building reliable, secure applications in today’s fast-paced development environments.

title: Troubleshooting Networks: A Beginner’s Guide to Problem Solving
description: Troubleshooting Networks: A Beginner’s Guide to Problem Solving is an essential course for those preparing for the CompTIA Network+ certification exam. Designed for newcomers to networking, this course builds on prior learning by focusing on troubleshooting methodologies, Ethernet and Wi-Fi issues, and common network-related problems. You'll learn to apply structured troubleshooting techniques, identify issues across different network layers, and analyze errors effectively. While the Network+ exam emphasizes theory over hands-on configuration, this course equips you with the critical thinking skills needed to diagnose and resolve network problems confidently.

title: Using APIs
description: Using APIs is an essential course for anyone looking to enhance their skills in working with network APIs. You’ll start with an overview of what APIs are, how to call them, and how to select the appropriate API style for your needs. Through practical examples, you’ll explore various network API styles and learn the fundamentals of creating API clients and effective API design. By the end of this course, you’ll have a solid understanding of APIs and the skills to confidently implement them in real-world scenarios.

title: Software Development & Design
description: Embark on your journey with Software Development & Design, a comprehensive course designed to build your expertise in designing and developing robust software systems. You'll start by exploring software architecture fundamentals, architectural patterns, and various software development models. Dive into essential topics like software testing, quality attributes, scalability, and high availability, along with maintainable design principles and performance management. Gain practical skills in version control and release management using Git, including branching strategies and workflows. By the end, you’ll have a strong foundation to effectively design, implement, and manage software solutions with high-quality standards.

title: Automating VXLAN BGP EVPN with Cisco Nexus Dashboard Fabric Controller (NDFC)
description: Automating VXLAN BGP EVPN with Cisco Nexus Dashboard Fabric Controller (NDFC) is an advanced training course designed to guide you through the automation of data center fabrics using Cisco NDFC. You'll explore core concepts and real-world implementations of VXLAN BGP EVPN, learn how to deploy fabrics using LAN Classic and Easy Fabric modes, and dive deep into fabric provisioning, validation, and troubleshooting workflows. Through detailed modules and demonstrations, you'll gain hands-on experience in deploying automation templates, leveraging REST APIs, and integrating with Ansible. Whether you're optimizing an existing network or building new fabric environments, this course empowers you to automate confidently with Cisco’s powerful data center orchestration platform.

title: Foundations of Networking Concepts & Protocols
description: Foundations of Networking Concepts and Protocols" is a beginner-friendly, video-based course designed to help individuals with no prior technical experience build a solid understanding of computer networking. The course begins with a clear explanation of what a computer network is and progresses to identifying various types of networking cables and understanding how data flows across a network. Learners will explore fundamental protocols like Ethernet, IPv4, and IPv6, gain a basic overview of essential network devices such as routers, switches, and firewalls, and learn the roles these components play in maintaining network connectivity and security. Additionally, the course introduces common application protocols like HTTP, FTP, LDAP, and TCP, offering insight into how networks support everyday tasks. To prepare students for modern networking, the course concludes with an introduction to emerging technologies like Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Cloud Networking. This course is perfect for anyone looking to take their first steps into the world of networking.

title: Network Threats & Defenses for Beginners
description: "Network Threats and Defenses for Beginners" is designed for those with a basic understanding of networking but little to no knowledge of cybersecurity. This course introduces key security concepts, including attack categories, encryption, access control, and overlooked security risks. You'll explore threats like phishing, malware, and denial-of-service attacks while learning about encryption technologies and authentication methods such as single sign-on and AAA. While this course does not cover hands-on implementation or troubleshooting, it provides a strong foundation in network security principles, helping you build awareness of modern threats and defenses in today's digital landscape.

title: API Penetration Testing
description: Unlock the skills needed to secure modern applications with API Penetration Testing, an in-depth course focused on assessing the security of APIs. This course covers essential areas such as identifying common API vulnerabilities, understanding authentication and authorization mechanisms, and testing for issues like broken object-level authorization, injection flaws, and security misconfigurations. You’ll explore techniques to evaluate RESTful and SOAP APIs, learn methods for bypassing protections, and gain hands-on experience with tools to automate and enhance your testing. By the end, you’ll be prepared to effectively analyze and protect APIs against sophisticated threats.

title: Software Development Security for CISSP
description: Complete your CISSP journey with Software Development Security for CISSP, the final step in mastering Domain 8 of the CISSP certification. This course focuses on integrating security into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC), covering models, DevOps practices, and operational safeguards. You'll enhance your understanding of programming languages, libraries, and tools while learning to implement critical security measures. Advanced topics include API security, web application protection, and mobile code controls, ensuring you're equipped for evolving threats. With a strong emphasis on database, system, and acquired software security, this course prepares you to secure software processes and achieve CISSP standards.

title: Server-Side Attacks
description:
In modern web applications, server-side vulnerabilities represent some of the most prevalent and impactful attack surfaces for penetration testers. With the rise of complex web application architectures—layered systems, microservices, and APIs—server-side components are more exposed to risks than ever before. When exploited, these vulnerabilities can result in sensitive data exposure, unauthorized access, or full system compromise, making them critical targets for offensive security testing.

This course covers a comprehensive range of topics designed to enhance the skills of professional web application penetration testers. It begins with an overview of Modern Web Application Architecture, exploring the components, layers, and models like layered architecture, microservices, and serverless. The course then dives into key server-side vulnerabilities, like SSRF, covering basic and advanced exploitation techniques and attack chains. This course will also introduce you to the serialization and deserialization process, focusing on insecure vulnerabilities, what causes them, and how they can be exploited. Practical exploitation techniques are explored across language-specific deserialization, including PHP Object Injection, Java deserialization, and Python deserialization. This combination of foundational knowledge and hands-on techniques ensures testers are equipped to identify and exploit modern server-side attack surfaces effectively.

title: Filter Evasion & WAF Bypass Techniques
description: Learn to outsmart security filters with Filter Evasion & WAF Bypass Techniques, a specialized course designed to enhance your penetration testing and cybersecurity skills. This course explores methods to bypass Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) and evade security filters, covering techniques such as encoding, obfuscation, and payload manipulation. You’ll practice various approaches to circumvent common filters and develop strategies to handle sophisticated WAF configurations while gaining insights into how attackers exploit weaknesses in filter settings. By the end, you’ll be equipped to assess filter defenses and improve security measures to resist advanced evasion techniques.

title: Cisco Network Services Orchestrator (NSO)
description:
Cisco Network Services Orchestrator (NSO) is a powerful software platform that provides automation and orchestration capabilities to manage and deploy network services across traditional and virtualized networks. In this course, you will master the essentials of Cisco NSO, starting with detailed step-by-step guidance on first-time installation and setup. Then, you will delve deeper into NSO's robust services and API capabilities, which are used to unlock advanced automation and integration capabilities.
By the end of the course, you'll have the skills to leverage Cisco NSO to streamline network management, and to provide scalable and efficient service delivery. This course is perfect for network engineers and IT professionals seeking to modernize their network operations.

title: Security Operations for CISSP
description: Continue advancing your CISSP expertise with Security Operations for CISSP, a comprehensive course designed to deepen your understanding of security operations. You’ll explore foundational concepts like investigations, forensics, evidence management, and electronic discovery, alongside advanced topics such as continuous monitoring, threat intelligence, and AI in security. The course also covers essential practices like patch management, incident response, and business continuity planning. By mastering these skills, you’ll gain the expertise needed to protect resources, maintain operational resilience, and uphold critical security standards, positioning you for success in achieving CISSP certification.

title: Advanced Injection Attacks
description: Master the art of uncovering and exploiting some of web application's most critical injection-based vulnerabilities. This course dives deep into injection attacks, going beyond traditional injection-based vulnerabilities. Learn the fundamentals of SQL Injection, automation with SQLMap, and advanced SQLi techniques like Out-of-Band and Second-Order attacks, and expand your expertise with NoSQL, LDAP, ORM, and XML Injection, including XXE exploitation. This course will equip you with the practical skills to effectively identify and exploit these vulnerabilities, ensuring you're prepared for real-world penetration testing scenarios.

title: Understanding NAT44, NAT64, 6RD, MAP & DS Lite
description: Explore the essentials of IPv4-to-IPv6 transition with Understanding NAT44, NAT64, 6RD, MAP & DS Lite. This course provides an in-depth overview of key network address translation techniques, including NAT44, NAT64, MAP-T, 6RD, and DS-Lite. You'll learn how each approach facilitates seamless IPv6 adoption, ensures compatibility with IPv4 networks, and supports modern connectivity needs. By mastering these technologies, you'll be equipped to implement scalable and efficient network solutions, making this course an invaluable resource for network engineers and IT professionals navigating the IPv6 transition.

title: Implementing BGP - IPv4 & IPv6
description: Implementing BGP - IPv4 & IPv6 is a comprehensive course designed to equip you with the skills to configure and optimize Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) for both IPv4 and IPv6 networks. You'll explore essential concepts like iBGP, eBGP, prefix advertisement, and route reflectors, while mastering advanced topics such as address-family types, path selection mechanisms, and key attributes like weight, local preference, and MED. With hands-on guidance in deploying features like additional paths and PIC, this course ensures you're prepared to implement and verify robust BGP configurations for scalable and efficient network performance.

title: Route Policy Language (RPL)
description: Route Policy Language (RPL) is an essential course designed to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of RPL and its role in network routing. You’ll explore the fundamentals of Route Policy Language, learn how to describe its functions, and gain practical skills in implementing RPL with IS-IS, OSPF/OSPFv3, and BGP protocols. By mastering these concepts, you’ll enhance your ability to optimize and control routing behavior across diverse network environments. Whether you're a network engineer or aspiring professional, this course equips you with the expertise to confidently work with advanced routing policies.

title: Security Assessment & Testing  for CISSP
description: Security Assessment & Testing for CISSP is a comprehensive course designed to prepare you for Domain 6 of the CISSP certification. You’ll explore key concepts such as vulnerability assessments, penetration testing, audits, and compliance checks, alongside practical techniques like log management, fuzzing, and breach attack simulations. The course also delves into account management, disaster recovery, and generating actionable reports from test outputs. Whether you’re analyzing security processes or facilitating audits, this course equips you with the expertise to assess, test, and strengthen security systems effectively.

title: Authentication & Session Management Testing
description: Authentication & Session Management Testing is an advanced course designed for experienced web application penetration testers and bug bounty hunters. It delves into modern authentication mechanisms, authentication testing techniques, and session management vulnerabilities. This course also delves deep into Key topics including testing authentication mechanisms, identifying session management flaws, token-based authentication security, JWT vulnerabilities, oAuth exploitation, and bypassing 2FA. This course aims to equip web application pentesters with the knowledge and expertise required to identify and exploit authentication and session management vulnerabilities effectively in modern web applications and APIs.

title: Intro to Advanced Web Application Penetration Testing
description:
Advanced Web Application Penetration Testing techniques are essential for security professionals aiming to stay ahead in the rapidly evolving web application security landscape. As web applications become increasingly complex, web application penetration testers need to stay updated with the latest tools, techniques, and vulnerabilities. This course equips penetration testers with the critical skills and knowledge to identify and exploit these vulnerabilities and misconfigurations. 

The course covers essential topics including web app pentesting methodology, the OWASP Top 10, and the Web Security Testing Guide (WSTG). Students will learn the intricacies of planning and scoping a web app pentest, along with key techniques such as reconnaissance, fingerprinting, crawling, scanning, and assessing session security. This course provides the practical skills needed to identify and exploit vulnerabilities in modern web applications.

title: Security Monitoring Challenges
description: Many challenges exist that make it more difficult to safeguard networked environments properly. In this course, we'll start with an overview of security monitoring, and then dive into challenges related to encryption and network monitoring. We'll also explore attacker tactics, including detection evasion, data exfiltration, network traffic manipulation, and pivoting. Each section expands on the challenges these topics pose to effective security monitoring and information on how modern controls can detect and mitigate them. By the end, you’ll have a well-rounded understanding of the challenges in monitoring complex infrastructures, enhancing your ability to protect and secure digital assets.

title: Endpoint Telemetry & Analysis
description: Endpoint Telemetry and Analysis is a comprehensive course designed to help you master endpoint monitoring and data analysis across various systems. You’ll begin with foundational concepts like endpoint logs, network ports, and user accounts to establish a solid grounding in host telemetry. As you progress, you'll dive into specialized analysis techniques for Windows and Linux environments, exploring processes, system events, permissions, and critical security controls. By the end of the course, you’ll have practical insights into endpoint security essentials, equipping you to detect and respond to potential threats across diverse operating systems.

title: Service Provider Architecture
description: Dive into Service Provider Architecture, a comprehensive course designed to give you a solid foundation in modern service provider networks. You'll explore core architectures like MPLS, Segment Routing, and routed optical networks, along with transport technologies such as xDSL and DWDM. Learn about mobility architectures for 5G, Cisco's IOS software stack, and the essentials of virtualization, including NFV and containers. Delve into advanced Quality of Service (QoS) models and robust security measures across control, management, and data planes. This course equips you with the skills to master cutting-edge service provider technologies and security protocols.

title: Cisco Networking Essentials
description: This introductory course is designed for individuals who are completely new to Cisco networking and have no prior experience with the Cisco IOS command-line interface (CLI). The course provides a solid foundation in Cisco networking, covering essential topics such as identifying interfaces, cabling, and hardware components, along with understanding basic networking concepts like IP addressing, subnets, and the OSI model. The course focuses on practical knowledge of the Cisco IOS software through specific videos on the command-line interface, enabling learners to understand and navigate the IOS environment. By the end, students will gain a strong conceptual grasp of Cisco networking, making it easier to build on these basics in more hands-on environments later.

title: Classifying Intrusion Events Into Categories
description: This course, a critical component of the Cisco CyberOps Associate learning path, focuses on documenting and analyzing intrusion events using two proven methodologies: the Cyber Kill Chain and the Diamond Model of Intrusion Analysis. This course provides a step-by-step approach to understanding and applying these frameworks while also introducing you to the MITRE ATT&CK knowledge base. You'll gain a high-level overview of its components and how they can be used to strengthen security strategies. Whether you're new to cybersecurity or looking to enhance your analysis skills, this course will equip you with valuable tools for threat detection and response.

title: Introduction to Cloud Security
description: This course provides an introduction to cloud security, starting with an overview of cloud basics and cloud computing models. It covers key topics such as the Shared Responsibility Model, essential cloud security tools, and assessment techniques. You'll gain insight into how modern DevOps practices, containers, serverless computing, and container orchestration impact cloud security. Additionally, this course explores cloud security requirements, common threats, and best practices to protect cloud environments. By the end, learners will have a foundational understanding of securing cloud-based services and infrastructures.

title: Introduction to Digital Forensics
description: Explore the fundamentals of digital forensics with Introduction to Digital Forensics, an immersive course tailored for those seeking foundational knowledge in the field. Designed in line with the Cisco CyberOps Associate certification, this course introduces key forensic concepts such as evidence collection, preservation, and the basics of reverse engineering. You’ll also dive into endpoint forensics, examining Windows processes, services, memory, registry, and file systems, as well as Linux forensics fundamentals. By mastering these core topics, you'll build a strong foundational understanding of digital forensics and its critical role in cybersecurity.

title: Identity & Access Management  for CISSP
description: Identity & Access Management for CISSP is a vital course for cybersecurity professionals seeking to master identity and access control systems. This course covers key topics such as physical and logical access controls, identification, authentication methods (including 2FA, MFA, and FIDO), and the challenges of modern security systems. You'll also explore critical areas like authorization, accountability, and common access control errors. By implementing authentication systems like SSO, Kerberos, SAML, and federated identity management, you'll gain practical skills to strengthen security frameworks across various environments.

title: Understanding L3VPNs & IPv6 VPNs
description: This course offers a detailed examination of Layer 3 Virtual Private Network (L3VPN) technology, with a specific focus on configurations and troubleshooting within both IPv4 and IPv6 frameworks. It begins with an overview of L3VPN and IPv6 VPN concepts, followed by step-by-step instructions on configuring and troubleshooting Intra-AS and Inter-AS L3VPNs, including detailed segments on Option A, B, and C scenarios. The course also delves into advanced topics such as Carrier Supporting Carrier configurations, Multicast VPNs (MVPNs), and Multipoint LDP (MLDP). Further lessons cover configuring Multi-Protocol BGP (MP-BGP) and various PE-CE routing protocols essential for managing VPN connectivity. This curriculum is ideal for network engineers who aim to master the complexities of implementing and managing L3VPNs across diverse network environments.

title: Understanding L2VPNs
description: This course is designed to provide an in-depth look at Layer 2 Virtual Private Networks (L2VPNs), focusing on the configuration, troubleshooting, and optimization of various L2VPN services. The course covers essential concepts and configurations for E-LANs, E-Line, and E-Tree services, along with detailed instruction on Ethernet VPNs (E-VPN), a key technology in modern network architectures. Participants will also explore traffic engineering techniques using RSVP-TE and Segment Routing with Traffic Engineering (SRTE) in conjunction with IS-IS and OSPF routing protocols. Additionally, the course delves into the implementation of Ethernet Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (E-OAM), equipping learners with the skills to ensure robust network performance and reliability. This curriculum is tailored for network engineers and professionals looking to specialize in the deployment and management of L2VPN architectures.

title: Introduction to VPN Architecture
description: This course offers a comprehensive exploration of various VPN technologies and protocols, tailored for individuals seeking to deepen their understanding of VPNs within network architecture. The course covers fundamental concepts such as Layer 2 and Layer 3 VPNs, Multi-Protocol Border Gateway Protocol (MP-BGP), and the intricacies of labels and routing in VPN contexts. Participants will learn about the differences between Inter-AS and Intra-AS L3VPNs, the roles of route distinguishers and targets, and the configuration and troubleshooting of core routing protocols and label-switched paths. Practical insights are provided through discussions on IOS XR and IOS XE configurations for Ethernet flow points and virtual circuits. This curriculum is designed to equip network professionals with the skills to effectively design, implement, and troubleshoot VPN solutions in modern networks.

title: Securing the Spanning-Tree
description: A majority of Layer-2 switched networks implement some version of the Spanning-Tree protocol. However, Spanning-Tree protocols are unprotected and vulnerable to unwanted topology changes and malicious attacks. This course is designed to teach you about four security-related protocols to mitigate the threat of most Spanning-Tree vulnerabilities. In this course you’ll learn about Root Guard, BPDU Guard, BPDU Filter, and Loop Guard, the problems they were designed to solve, how they operate, and the commands necessary to implement them. Each of these features will also be demonstrated in a lab environment.

title: AI & Cybersecurity
description: This course offers an overview of how Artificial Intelligence (AI) intersects with cybersecurity. Students will learn the basics of AI, its common types, and its applications in cyber defense. Key topics include the threats and risks posed by AI, strategies for secure AI usage, and the ethical considerations involved. The course equips students with the knowledge to effectively utilize AI in cybersecurity while addressing potential challenges and maintaining ethical standards.

title: Assessment Methodologies: Vulnerability Assessment
description: The Vulnerability Assessment course is designed for penetration testers and cybersecurity practitioners looking to enhance their ability to identify and evaluate security weaknesses in networks, applications, and systems. This course provides a comprehensive introduction to vulnerability assessment, distinguishing it from vulnerability scanning and penetration testing, while emphasizing its crucial role in the overall security lifecycle. Through hands-on labs using industry-standard tools like Nessus, and Nmap, you will learn to conduct thorough assessments, interpret findings, and prioritize vulnerabilities for remediation, equipping you with the skills needed to safeguard digital assets effectively.

title: Assessment Methodologies: Enumeration
description: This course delves into the crucial aspects of identifying and analyzing network services, a fundamental step in the penetration testing lifecycle. You will gain in-depth knowledge of using the Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) for advanced service detection and enumeration, which provides an automated and customizable approach to network scanning. The course covers the enumeration techniques for commonly encountered services such as SSH, FTP, SMB, and SMTP. Through practical lab demonstrations, you will master the skills to uncover service versions, identify potential vulnerabilities, and gather critical information that can be leveraged in subsequent penetration testing phases. This course will equip you with the expertise to enumerate network services and elevate your penetration testing capabilities efficiently.

title: Host & Network Penetration Testing: Network-Based Attacks
description: This course covers Network-Based Attacks. Here in this course, you will learn about the basics of attacks originating from network traffic and network services. Intercepting network traffic and utilizing network protocols to manipulate the flow of that traffic allows attackers to gain access to information intended for others. That information can be parlayed into other attacks, both network and system-based. Being familiar with the tools and techniques an adversary uses against the network will allow the penetration tester to best emulate a real attacker and provide the most value during their assessment.

title: Introducing Terraform for the Network Engineer
description: This course, "Terraform for Network Engineers," introduces Terraform, focusing on its application in network engineering. It begins by explaining the purpose of Terraform as an automation tool designed by HashiCorp for provisioning, configuring, and maintaining infrastructure across various environments, including cloud and on-premise systems. The course covers key concepts and terminology such as resources, providers, modules, and the Terraform state file, explaining how these elements work together to manage infrastructure as code. Additionally, the course walks through the Terraform workflow, emphasizing the importance of structured processes, isolation, safety, and controlled change management. Practical demonstrations and hands-on labs help solidify the learner's understanding of Terraform's capabilities in network environments.

title: An Introduction to AI & Machine Learning for the Network Engineer
description: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning can be terms that are overwhelming and frightening to some. But in this day and age, AI seems to be in the news almost every day. For the Network Engineer, utilizing AI and Machine Learning can greatly alleviate your daily workload. This course is designed for those who know absolutely nothing about AI and wish to learn the basic terminology and use cases behind it. Specifically geared for Network Engineers, you will learn about the various types of AI architectures, models, and subsets. You’ll be exposed to the differences between Supervised Learning, Unsupervised Learning, and Reinforcement Training. You’ll learn the relative strengths and weaknesses of different Machine Learning specialties and, most importantly, you’ll learn how AI (and specifically Generative AI) can make your life as a Network Engineer easier.

title: Assessment Methodologies: Auditing Fundamentals
description:
Understanding security auditing is essential for penetration testers because it equips them with the knowledge and skills necessary to evaluate and improve an organization's security posture. Security audits provide a systematic approach to identifying vulnerabilities, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements, and implementing best practices.

This course is designed to provide penetration testers and cybersecurity practitioners with a comprehensive understanding of security auditing principles, processes, and tools. In this course, participants will explore the critical role of security auditing within the broader scope of cybersecurity and how it complements penetration testing.

title: Cyber Security Essentials: Normalizing & Analyzing Data
description: A great portion of a cyber security analyst’s job is to analyze data. However, data must be structured and normalized prior to analysis otherwise its meaning and context can be lost…and incidents of compromise might be overlooked. This course will introduce you to the concept of data normalization as it pertains to cyber security solutions. You’ll learn why data normalization is important, some methods by which it can be automated, and some of the manual tasks involved when automation is not possible. You’ll also learn about the 5-Tuple and how this concept is critical to being able to effectively analyze networking data. An introduction to DNS Intelligence will be presented showcasing its ability to facilitate data analysis. Lastly, you’ll be introduced to some common methods of data analysis by learning about retrospective analysis, deterministic analysis, and probabilistic analysis.

title: Intrusion Analysis Overview
description: The Cisco CyberOps Associate certification covers a wide range of topics, from incident response and SOC operations to intrusion analysis and threat hunting. In this course, we’ll be focusing on a general overview of intrusion analysis and incident response. We’ll take a look at the planning that goes into incident response, including recommended policies that should be a part of any incident response plan. From there, we’ll go over the actual incident response process and the common activities in each phase of incident response, including how information sharing factors into the process. We will then talk about different types of common incident response teams, from the smaller internal IR teams in organizations to the national CERTs. We’ll wrap up the incident response section by looking at common security event artifacts that are frequently seen in many types of events. From there, we’ll look at threat hunting; starting with an overview of what threat hunting is and why it’s useful, and then the threat hunting process and steps, including how organizations can gauge the maturity level of their threat hunting programs. We’ll then wrap up the course by looking at the MITRE ATT&CK framework; what it is, and how it can be used to assist in threat-hunting programs, and also with incident response and intrusion analysis.

title: Host & Network Penetration Testing: Social Engineering
description:
Social engineering in the context of penetration testing (pentesting) refers to the practice of manipulating individuals into divulging confidential information or performing actions that compromise security. It plays a crucial role in pentesting by identifying vulnerabilities in an organization's human element, often considered the weakest link in security. People or employees are the hardest part of an enterprise network to secure. Even with the best technology and defenses, an attacker can still compromise a system through poor practices or accidental mistakes. Malicious actors exploit this weakness, making it one of the most effective ways to infiltrate an organization. Social engineering exploits psychological aspects such as trust, fear, curiosity, and the inherent willingness of employees to help. Techniques include phishing, pretexting, baiting, and tailgating, aiming to trick employees into revealing passwords, clicking on malicious links, or granting unauthorized access. This testing helps organizations understand their susceptibility to human-based attacks and develop more effective training and security measures.


This course will introduce you to Social Engineering as a concept and practice, it will also provide you with a historical understanding of Social Engineering and will introduce you to the various Social Engineering Techniques leveraged by attackers.  You will also learn when and how to leverage Pretexting to exploit human psychology and emotions when communicating with individuals and organizations. You will also learn how to plan, set up, and orchestrate a Phishing campaign with open source Phishing frameworks like Gophish.

title: Web Application Penetration Testing: Introduction to the Web & HTTP Protocol
description:
As a Penetration Tester, it is vitally important to understand how web applications work, how they are secured, how they communicate with web browsers, the threats/vulnerabilities affecting modern web applications, and how to perform a professional security assessment on web applications.

This course will provide a solid understanding of essential web application security concepts and practices, including common attack vectors, security risks, and the importance of secure coding practices. It also covers important aspects of web application architecture, the technologies and components that make up a web application stack, and how browsers and web applications communicate with each other over HTTP/S.

title: Communication & Network Security  for CISSP
description: This course is a comprehensive deep dive into Domain 4 of the CISSP certification, focusing on the layers of the OSI model and the critical aspects of network security. Through detailed video lectures, this course covers everything from the basics of cables and fiber optics to advanced topics like virtual networks and security protocols. Participants will gain understanding of network functionalities, such as remote authentication, VPNs, firewalls, and various network attacks. Each layer of the OSI model is dissected in depth, exploring its components, associated technologies, and potential vulnerabilities. This course is essential for anyone aiming to master the communication and network security requirements for CISSP certification, providing both theoretical knowledge and practical security insights.

title: Foundations of Cyber Security: Network Telemetry & Data Analytics
description: Cyber Security professionals often implement applications (ie, “agents”) that can obtain telemetry data from various critical host devices (such as webservers, fileservers, and employee laptops) to spot malicious activity related to those devices. But have you considered the need to extract telemetry data from the network itself? For those unfamiliar with the term “telemetry” this course starts by introducing and explaining that topic. It then proceeds to explain why telemetry should be extracted from network devices and various ways to accomplish that task. You’ll be introduced to large-scale logging collectors such as Splunk, ELK Stack, and Graylog. You’ll see how the Cisco Firepower Management Center can extract and display telemetry data received from Cisco Firepower appliances. You’ll also learn how obtaining packet captures through tools such as Wireshark or tcpdump can be important elements of network telemetry and much more. Whether you’re studying for a certification like Cisco’s CyberOps Associate, or simply interested in the concept of network telemetry, this course is for you!

title: Security Operations Management
description: The Cisco CyberOps Associate certification covers a wide range of topics, from incident response and SOC operations to intrusion analysis and threat hunting. In this course, we’ll be focusing on security operations management. To start, you’ll learn about various identity and access management topics - such as the identity and access life cycle, secure password management, and directory management. From there, we’ll take a look at log collection and analysis using security information and event management systems, also known as a SIEM. We’ll then dive into asset management strategies including mobile device management and we’ll look at what change management is and why it’s important for any organization. To wrap up the course, you’ll learn about different ways that vulnerabilities can be discovered and disclosed, where to find information about vulnerabilities, and what the analysis and remediation steps look like.

title: Webex Calling & Cloud Connected UC
description: Unlock the full potential of modern communication with our comprehensive course, "Webex Calling and Cloud Connected UC." Designed for IT professionals, network engineers, and communications specialists, this course delves into the essentials of Cisco's Webex Calling and Cloud Connected Unified Communications (UC) solutions. Participants will gain hands-on experience and in-depth knowledge of Webex Calling's cloud-based voice and collaboration services, exploring features such as call routing and integration with other Webex services.

title: Security Attacks & Vulnerabilities
description: As the main reason why cyber security should be a critical part of any organization's overall strategy, in this course, we'll explore attacks and vulnerabilities. We'll look at different types of threat actor groups what their primary motivators are, and some methods to collect various pieces of intelligence about their tactics, techniques, and procedures. In this course, you'll learn about the most common types of attacks that threat actors employ, including reconnaissance, social engineering, application, and network attacks. From there, we'll go into what commonly makes these attacks possible: vulnerabilities. We'll go over the main types of vulnerabilities, and dive deeper into injection vulnerabilities, as well as application- and authentication-based vulnerabilities, and others. This course is structured to fit into the Cisco CyberOps Associate certification learning path but contains useful information and skills to benefit any cybersecurity professional.

title: IP VPN Technology Fundamentals
description: Any study of network security or Cybersecurity will, by necessity, have to include the topic of IP VPNs.  IP VPNs are prevalent across all forms of organizations, and networks, and are even incorporated into all web browsers. If your goal is to learn about what IP VPNs are, why they are beneficial, the categories of IP VPNs, as well as the most common protocols and features used to implement IP VPNs, this course is where you want to be. In this course, after learning about the foundations of what IP VPNs are, their benefits, and categories of IP VPNs you’ll learn about protocols such as IPsec, SSL, TLS, ISAKMP, IKE, DMVPN, and GETVPN which are practical and ubiquitous protocols used in modern networks to implement these types of VPNs.

title: Active Directory Penetration Testing
description:
Active Directory (AD) penetration testing is a critical skill for modern penetration testers and red teamers seeking to assess and exploit the security of modern corporate networks. This course provides a comprehensive introduction to AD penetration testing, covering essential techniques and tools used to identify and exploit vulnerabilities within AD environments. Through hands-on labs and real-world scenarios, you will gain the knowledge and practical experience needed to conduct effective penetration tests against Active Directory environments and strengthen your overall offensive skillset.

In this course, you will get an introduction to Active Directory, learn how it works, and the components that make up Active Directory. After which, you will learn how to perform Active Directory reconnaissance, and enumeration through the use of various techniques and tools like PowerView and BloodHound. You will then delve into Kerberos attacks like AS-REP Roasting and Kerberoasting, where you will learn how to identify and exploit Kerberoastable users. This course also covers Lateral Movement techniques like Pass-the-Ticket attacks (PTT) and advanced persistence techniques like Silver Ticket and Golden Ticket Attacks. After completing this course, you will be proficient in conducting effective AD penetration tests and strengthening the security posture of corporate networks.

title: Exploit Development: Buffer Overflows
description:
This course is designed to equip penetration testers and red teamers with the essential knowledge and skills required to identify and exploit Buffer Overflow vulnerabilities. This course focuses specifically on the development of exploits targeting buffer overflow vulnerabilities, including stack-based overflows and Structured Exception Handling (SEH) overflows. Exploit development skills are of paramount importance in the cyber security landscape, as they enable security professionals to identify, analyze, and mitigate vulnerabilities in software applications before they can be exploited by malicious actors.
